title: Somer–Lucas pseudoprime
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, in particular <a href="number%20theory">number theory</a>, an <a href="odd%20number">odd</a> <a href="composite%20number">composite number</a> "N" is a Somer–Lucas "d"-<a href="pseudoprime">pseudoprime</a> (with given "d" ≥ 1) if there exists a nondegenerate <a href="Lucas%20sequence">Lucas sequence</a> formula_1 with the discriminant formula_2 such that formula_3 and the rank appearance of "N" in the sequence "U"("P", "Q") is
where formula_5 is the <a href="Jacobi%20symbol">Jacobi symbol</a>.
Applications.
Unlike the standard <a href="Lucas%20pseudoprime">Lucas pseudoprime</a>s, there is no known efficient primality test using the Lucas "d"-pseudoprimes. Hence they are not generally used for computation.
See also.
Lawrence Somer, in his 1985 thesis, also defined the <a href="Somer%20d-pseudoprime">Somer d-pseudoprime</a>s. They are described in brief on page 117 of Ribenbaum 1996.
